itemDescription: British journalist and Liberal Unionist politician

wikipedia_page.main: Arthur Ralph Douglas Elliot-Murray-Kynynmound (17 December 1846 – 12 February 1923), known as Arthur Elliot, was a British journalist and Liberal Unionist politician.

link_mentions.page: Robert Cecil, 1st Viscount Cecil of Chelwood
response: In January 1908, Cecil wrote to fellow Unionist free trader Arthur Elliot: "To me, the greatest necessity of all is to preserve, if possible, a foothold for Free Trade within the Unionist party. For, if not, I and others who think like me, will be driven to imperil either free trade or other causes such as religious education, the House of Lords, and even the Union, which seem to us of equal importance".Sykes, p. 173. In March 1910 Cecil and his brother Lord Hugh, unsuccessfully appealed to Chamberlain that he should postpone advocating food taxes at the next election in order to concentrate on opposing Irish Home Rule.Sykes, pp. 215-216.

*The Hon. Arthur Ralph Douglas Elliot-Murray-Kynynmound (known as Arthur Elliott), second son of the third Earl, was a Conservative politician and served as Financial Secretary to the Treasury in 1903.

response: Arthur Elliot, MP for Roxburghshire 1880–92 and City of Durham 1898–1906, who had a leg amputated at age four after a fall.
Arthur Elliot or Elliott may refer to:

link_mentions.page: List of MPs elected in the 1880 United Kingdom general election

response: Gilbert Elliot-Murray-Kynynmound, 4th Earl of Minto, and Arthur Elliot were his elder brothers.
